answer_llm:
If you encounter "Allocator ran out of memory" errors while running TensorFlow on your machine, you can try the following solution: Add the following code at the beginning of your notebook:

```python
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
```

This configuration allows TensorFlow to allocate GPU memory dynamically, which can help alleviate the memory errors. In most cases, this should resolve the issue, although there may be rare instances where the error could still appear temporarily during an epoch. If that happens, simply rerun your code.
answer_orig:
If you are running tensorflow on your own machine and you start getting the following errors:
Allocator (GPU_0_bfc) ran out of memory trying to allocate 6.88GiB with freed_by_count=0. The caller indicates that this is not a failure, but this may mean that there could be performance gains if more memory were available.
Try adding this code in a cell at the beginning of your notebook:
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
After doing this most of my issues went away. I say most because there was one instance when I still got the error once more, but only during one epoch. I ran the code again, right after it finished, and I never saw the error again.
Added by Martin Uribe
question: What should I do if I get Allocator ran out of memory errors while running TensorFlow on my machine?

answer_llm:
To configure TensorFlow to solve memory allocation issues on your machine, you can use the following code snippet at the beginning of your notebook:

```python
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
```

This code allows TensorFlow to allocate memory as needed instead of reserving all available memory upfront. After implementing this, most memory allocation issues should be resolved, although there might be rare instances where the error could still occur.
answer_orig:
If you are running tensorflow on your own machine and you start getting the following errors:
Allocator (GPU_0_bfc) ran out of memory trying to allocate 6.88GiB with freed_by_count=0. The caller indicates that this is not a failure, but this may mean that there could be performance gains if more memory were available.
Try adding this code in a cell at the beginning of your notebook:
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
After doing this most of my issues went away. I say most because there was one instance when I still got the error once more, but only during one epoch. I ran the code again, right after it finished, and I never saw the error again.
Added by Martin Uribe
question: How can I configure TensorFlow to solve memory allocation issues on my machine?

answer_llm:
To help with performance gains if you encounter memory errors while running TensorFlow, you can configure TensorFlow to allow GPU memory growth. You can add the following code at the beginning of your notebook:

```python
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
```

This configuration may alleviate the memory errors you are experiencing, allowing TensorFlow to use memory more efficiently.

answer_llm:
When creating the virtual environment in session 10.3 with pipenv and trying to run gateway.py, you may encounter the following error: 

`TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly.` 

This error indicates that the generated code is out of date and must be regenerated with protoc version >= 3.19.0. To work around this issue, you can either downgrade the protobuf package to version 3.20.x or lower, or set the environment variable `PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python`, though this latter option will result in slower performance due to using pure-Python parsing. More information on this can be found at the link provided in the context.
answer_orig:
In session 10.3, when creating the virtual environment with pipenv and trying to run the script gateway.py, you might get this error:
TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly.
If this call came from a _pb2.py file, your generated code is out of date and must be regenerated with protoc >= 3.19.0.
If you cannot immediately regenerate your protos, some other possible workarounds are:
1. Downgrade the protobuf package to 3.20.x or lower.
2. Set PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python (but this will use pure-Python parsing and will be much slower).
More information: https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/news/2022-05-06#python-updates
This will happen if your version of protobuf is one of the newer ones. As a workaround, you can fix the protobuf version to an older one. In my case I got around the issue by creating the environment with:
pipenv install --python 3.9.13 requests grpcio==1.42.0 flask gunicorn \
keras-image-helper tensorflow-protobuf==2.7.0 protobuf==3.19.6
Added by Ángel de Vicente
question: What error might occur when creating the virtual environment in session 10.3 with pipenv and running gateway.py?

answer_llm:
To resolve the TypeError issue caused by the recent version of protobuf in session 10.3, you can take the following steps:

1. **Downgrade the protobuf package** to a version that is less than or equal to 3.20.x. For example, you can use the command:
   ```
   pipenv install protobuf==3.20.1
   ```

2. If you cannot immediately downgrade, you can **set the environment variable** to use pure-Python parsing by running:
   ```
   export PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python
   ```
   Keep in mind that this will make parsing slower.

3. If your generated code is out of date, consider regenerating your protos with `protoc >= 3.19.0`.

These steps should help you get around the TypeError issue.

answer_llm:
If WSL cannot connect to the Docker daemon, you can follow these steps:

1. Check if Docker Desktop is still connected to your WSL Linux distro. Sometimes, the connection may be lost.
2. Open your Docker Desktop settings.
3. Navigate to the "Resources" section and click on "WSL Integration."
4. Enable additional distros, even if the additional distro is the same as the default WSL distro.

If you are still experiencing issues, consider reinstalling Docker. Remove the Docker installation from WSL and install Docker Desktop on your host machine (Windows).
answer_orig:
Due to the uncertainties associated with machines, sometimes you can get the error message like this when you try to run a docker command:
”Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the docker daemon running?”
Solution: The solution is simple. The Docker Desktop might no longer be connecting to the WSL Linux distro. What you need to do is go to your Docker Desktop setting and then click on resources. Under resources, click on WSL Integration. You will get a tab like the image below:
Just enable additional distros. That’s all. Even if the additional distro is the same as the default WSL distro.
Odimegwu David
question: What should I do if WSL cannot connect to the Docker daemon?

answer_llm:
To resolve the error 'Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the docker daemon running?', you can take the following steps based on your environment:

1. **For WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux)**:
   - Ensure that Docker Desktop is installed on your host Windows machine.
   - Check your Docker Desktop settings. Go to resources, then WSL Integration, and enable additional distros, even if it's the same as the default WSL distro.

2. **For Linux**:
   - Start the Docker daemon using one of the following commands:
     - `sudo dockerd`
     - `sudo service docker start`

Make sure that Docker is running to avoid this connection issue.

answer_llm:
If the HPA instance doesn't work correctly even after installing the latest Metrics Server, you can try two solutions:

1. **Edit the Metrics Server Deployment**:
   Run the command:
   ```
   kubectl edit deploy -n kube-system metrics-server
   ```
   Look for the line:
   ```
   args:
   - --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
   ```
   Add this line in the middle:
   ```
   - --kubelet-insecure-tls
   ```
   It should look like this:
   ```
   args:
   - --kubelet-insecure-tls
   - --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
   ```
   Save the changes and run:
   ```
   kubectl get hpa
   ```

2. **Use an Alternative Metrics Server Deployment File**:
   Run the command:
   ```
   kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Peco602/ml-zoomcamp/main/10-kubernetes/kube-config/metrics-server-deployment.yaml
   ```
   This deployment file already includes the `- --kubelet-insecure-tls` option.

After applying either solution, check the HPA again.
answer_orig:
In case the HPA instance does not run correctly even after installing the latest version of Metrics Server from the components.yaml manifest with:
>>kubectl apply -f https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/metrics-server/releases/latest/download/components.yaml
And the targets still appear as <unknown>
Run >>kubectl edit deploy -n kube-system metrics-server
And search for this line:
args:
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
Add this line in the middle:  - --kubelet-insecure-tls
So that it stays like this:
args:
- --kubelet-insecure-tls
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
Save and run again >>kubectl get hpa
Added by Marilina Orihuela
question: What should be done if the HPA instance doesn't work correctly even after installing the latest Metrics Server?

answer_llm:
To edit the metrics-server deployment and fix the HPA issue, you can run the following command:

```bash

```

Then, search for the line that starts with `args:` and locate this line:

```
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
```

You need to add this line in the middle:

```
- --kubelet-insecure-tls
```

After making this change, the `args` section should look like this:

```
args:
- --kubelet-insecure-tls
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
```

Finally, save the changes and run the command:

```bash
kubectl get hpa
```

This should help resolve the HPA issue.

To resolve the 'Could not install packages due to an OSError: [WinError 5] Access is denied' error when installing libraries in Windows, consider using the `--user` option with the pip install command. You can run the following command to install the libraries:

```bash
pip --user install grpcio==1.42.0 tensorflow-serving-api==2.7.0
```

This should help bypass the permissions issue you are encountering.

answer_llm:
The error that occurs when running `gateway.py` after modifying the code in video 10.3 is:

```
TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly.
```

This error arises when the version of protobuf being used is incompatible. Specifically, it indicates that your generated code is out of date and must be regenerated with protoc >= 3.19.0.
answer_orig:
Problem description
I was getting the below error message when I run gateway.py after modifying the code & creating virtual environment in  video 10.3 :
File "C:\Users\Asia\Data_Science_Code\Zoompcamp\Kubernetes\gat.py", line 9, in <module>
from tensorflow_serving.apis import predict_pb2
File "C:\Users\Asia\.virtualenvs\Kubernetes-Ge6Ts1D5\lib\site-packages\tensorflow_serving\apis\predict_pb2.py", line 14, in <module>
from tensorflow.core.framework import tensor_pb2 as tensorflow_dot_core_dot_framework_dot_tensor__pb2
File "C:\Users\Asia\.virtualenvs\Kubernetes-Ge6Ts1D5\lib\site-packages\tensorflow\core\framework\tensor_pb2.py", line 14, in <module>
from tensorflow.core.framework import resource_handle_pb2 as tensorflow_dot_core_dot_framework_dot_resource__handle__pb2
File "C:\Users\Asia\.virtualenvs\Kubernetes-Ge6Ts1D5\lib\site-packages\tensorflow\core\framework\resource_handle_pb2.py", line 14, in <module>
from tensorflow.core.framework import tensor_shape_pb2 as tensorflow_dot_core_dot_framework_dot_tensor__shape__pb2
File "C:\Users\Asia\.virtualenvs\Kubernetes-Ge6Ts1D5\lib\site-packages\tensorflow\core\framework\tensor_shape_pb2.py", line 36, in <module>
_descriptor.FieldDescriptor(
File "C:\Users\Asia\.virtualenvs\Kubernetes-Ge6Ts1D5\lib\site-packages\google\protobuf\descriptor.py", line 560, in __new__
_message.Message._CheckCalledFromGeneratedFile()
TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly.
If this call came from a _pb2.py file, your generated code is out of date and must be regenerated with protoc >= 3.19.0.
If you cannot immediately regenerate your protos, some other possible workarounds are:
1. Downgrade the protobuf package to 3.20.x or lower.
2. Set PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python (but this will use pure-Python parsing and will be much slower).
Solution description:
Issue has been resolved by downgrading protobuf to version 3.20.1.
pipenv install protobuf==3.20.1
Asia Saeed
question: What error occurs when running gateway.py after modifying the code in video 10.3?

answer_llm:
The TypeError: "Descriptors cannot not be created directly" occurs due to a problem when running the script `gateway.py` after modifying the code and creating a virtual environment. Specifically, this error can arise if the version of the protobuf library in use is too new. The error message indicates that if the call originated from a `_pb2.py` file, the generated code is out of date and must be regenerated using protoc version 3.19.0 or later.

To resolve this issue without immediate regeneration of protos, you can take one of the following steps:
1. Downgrade the protobuf package to version 3.20.x or lower.
2. Set the environment variable `PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION` to `python`, although this will lead to slower performance due to using pure-Python parsing.

In a specific case, the issue was resolved by downgrading protobuf to version 3.20.1 using the command `pipenv install protobuf==3.20.1`.

question: What causes the TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly?

answer_llm:
To resolve the issue of your generated protobuf code being out of date, you have a couple of options:

1. **Regenerate your code**: Ensure you regenerate your protobuf code using `protoc` version 3.19.0 or newer.

2. **Workarounds**: If you cannot immediately regenerate your protos, you can try the following workarounds:
   - Downgrade the protobuf package to version 3.20.x or lower.
   - Set the environment variable `PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION` to `python`. Please note that this will use pure-Python parsing and will be significantly slower.

For instance, you can downgrade protobuf by running:
```bash
pipenv install protobuf==3.20.1
``` 

This should help resolve the issue you are experiencing.

These options may help you work around the issue until you can regenerate your protos.

answer_llm:
To install kubectl easily on Windows, you can use the terminal in Visual Studio Code (PowerShell). Follow the tutorial at this link: https://medium.com/@ggauravsigra/install-kubectl-on-windows-af77da2e6fff.

First, download kubectl with curl by using the command lines provided here: https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/tools/install-kubectl-windows/#install-kubectl-binary-with-curl-on-windows. After downloading, copy the exe file to a specific folder on your C drive. Then, add this folder path to the PATH in your environment variables to ensure kubectl is accessible from the command line.
answer_orig:
To install kubectl on windows using the terminal in vscode (powershell), I followed this tutorial: https://medium.com/@ggauravsigra/install-kubectl-on-windows-af77da2e6fff
I first downloaded kubectl with curl, with these command lines: https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/tools/install-kubectl-windows/#install-kubectl-binary-with-curl-on-windows
At step 3, I followed the tutorial with the copy of the exe file in a specific folder on C drive.
Then I added this folder path to PATH in my environment variables.
Kind can be installed the same way with the curl command on windows, by specifying a folder that will be added to the path environment variable.
Added by Mélanie Fouesnard

question: Where can I find the tutorial for installing kubectl using curl on Windows?

answer_llm:
To add kubectl to the PATH in environment variables on Windows, follow these steps:

1. First, download kubectl using curl by following the commands specified in the tutorial at https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/tools/install-kubectl-windows/#install-kubectl-binary-with-curl-on-windows.
2. Copy the downloaded executable (the exe file) to a specific folder on your C drive.
3. Add the folder path where you copied the kubectl executable to the PATH in your environment variables. 

This will enable you to run kubectl commands from any terminal on your system.

answer_llm:
To install kind using Choco, you first need to launch a PowerShell terminal with administrator privileges. Then, install the Choco library by executing the following command in PowerShell:

```powershell
Set-ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Scope Process -Force; [System.Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol = [System.Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol -bor 3072; iex ((New-Object System.Net.WebClient).DownloadString('https://chocolatey.org/install.ps1'))
```
answer_orig:

If you are having issues installing Kind through Windows Powershell and Choco Library, you can install Kind using Go instead. Here are the steps to do that:

1. Download and install Go from [here](https://go.dev/doc/install).
2. Confirm the installation by typing `go version` in Command Prompt.
3. Proceed to install Kind with the command: `go install sigs.k8s.io/kind@v0.20.0`.
4. Confirm the installation by running `kind --version`.

This method works perfectly for installing Kind.

answer_llm:
To resolve the 'connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused' issue with kubectl, you can follow these steps:

1. Delete your existing Kubernetes cluster with the command:
   ```
   kind delete cluster
   ```

2. Remove the Kubernetes configuration folder by running:
   ```
   rm -rf ~/.kube
   ```

3. Create a new Kubernetes cluster again using:
   ```
   kind create cluster
   ```

After following these steps, you should be able to run the command `kubectl get service` successfully.
answer_orig:
I ran into an issue where kubectl wasn't working.
I kept getting the following error:
kubectl get service
The connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused - did you specify the right host or port?
I searched online for a resolution, but everyone kept talking about creating an environment variable and creating some admin.config file in my home directory.
All hogwash.
The solution to my problem was to just start over.
kind delete cluster
rm -rf ~/.kube
kind create cluster
Now when I try the same command again:
kubectl get service
NAME         TYPE        CLUSTER-IP   EXTERNAL-IP   PORT(S)   AGE
kubernetes   ClusterIP   10.96.0.1    <none>        443/TCP   53s
Added by Martin Uribe
question: How can I resolve the 'connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused' issue with kubectl?

1. Deleted the existing cluster using the command: `kind delete cluster`.
2. Removed the `.kube` directory with the command: `rm -rf ~/.kube`.
3. Created a new cluster using the command: `kind create cluster`.

After these steps, he successfully ran the command `kubectl get service` and received the expected output.

answer_llm:
To solve the issue of running out of storage after building many Docker images, you should follow these steps:

1. Use the command `docker images` to check the images currently stored on your system and identify any superseded or duplicate models taking up space.
2. Remove the unwanted Docker images using `docker rmi <image_id>` for each image you wish to delete.
3. After removing the images, it’s important to free up the storage space that these images were occupying. To do this, run the command `docker system prune`. This command will help free up the storage that you might expect to recover by simply deleting images.

Remember, deleting Docker images alone does not free up space until you also perform a system prune.
answer_orig:
Problem description
Due to experimenting back and forth so much without care for storage, I just ran out of it on my 30-GB AWS instance.
My first reflex was to remove some zoomcamp directories, but of course those are mostly code so it didn’t help much.
Solution description
> docker images
revealed that I had over 20 GBs worth of superseded / duplicate models lying around, so I proceeded to > docker rmi
a bunch of those — but to no avail!
It turns out that deleting docker images does not actually free up any space as you might expect. After removing images, you also need to run
> docker system prune
See also: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/36799718/why-removing-docker-containers-and-images-does-not-free-up-storage-space-on-wind
Added by Konrad Mühlberg
question: How can I solve the issue of running out of storage after building many docker images?

answer_llm: Removing some zoomcamp directories didn't help in freeing up space because those directories mostly contain code, which does not significantly impact the storage used by Docker images. The actual issue was that there were over 20 GBs worth of superseded or duplicate Docker images. Simply removing these images does not free up space; you also need to run `docker system prune` to actually reclaim that space.

answer_llm: In Kubernetes resource specifications, the "m" in CPU values such as "100m" and "500m" stands for milliCPU, which is a unit of computing power representing one thousandth of a CPU core. Therefore, "100m" means the container is requesting 100 milliCPUs, equivalent to 0.1 CPU core, and "500m" means the container has a CPU limit of 500 milliCPUs, equivalent to 0.5 CPU core. This allows for fine-grained control over CPU resources, enabling the expression of CPU requirements and limits in a more granular way, especially when applications may not need a full CPU core.
answer_orig:
In Kubernetes resource specifications, such as CPU requests and limits, the "m" stands for milliCPU, which is a unit of computing power. It represents one thousandth of a CPU core.
cpu: "100m" means the container is requesting 100 milliCPUs, which is equivalent to 0.1 CPU core.
cpu: "500m" means the container has a CPU limit of 500 milliCPUs, which is equivalent to 0.5 CPU core.
These values are specified in milliCPUs to allow fine-grained control over CPU resources. It allows you to express CPU requirements and limits in a more granular way, especially in scenarios where your application might not need a full CPU core.
Added by Andrii Larkin

answer_llm:
If your kind cluster can't find any nodes after loading a Docker image, you should specify the cluster name using the `-n` option. For example, you can use the command:

```
kind -n your-cluster-name load docker-image your-image-name
```

Replace `your-cluster-name` with the name of your cluster and `your-image-name` with the name of the Docker image you are trying to load.
answer_orig:
Problem: Failing to load docker-image to cluster (when you’ved named a cluster)
kind load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001
ERROR: no nodes found for cluster "kind"
Solution: Specify cluster name with -n
kind -n clothing-model load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001
Andrew Katoch

question: How can I resolve the error 'no nodes found for cluster kind' when loading a Docker image using kind?

answer_llm:
To load a Docker image to a named kind cluster, you need to specify the cluster name using the `-n` option. The command would look like this:

```
kind -n <cluster-name> load docker-image <image-name>
```

For example, if your cluster is named "clothing-model" and the image you want to load is "zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001", you would use the following command:

```
kind -n clothing-model load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001
```

```
kind -n clothing-model load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001
```

This should resolve the issue.

kind load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001

Solution: Specify cluster name with -n
kind -n clothing-model load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001

To resolve the issue of 'kind' not being recognized as a command on Windows after installation, you need to follow these steps:

2. After renaming, place the `kind.exe` file in a specific folder.
3. Finally, make sure to add that folder to your system's PATH environment variable.

These steps should allow you to run the `kind` command successfully.

answer_llm:
To resolve the `TypeError: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'unbound_message'` when importing Flask, you should check the versions of Flask and Werkzeug you are using. This error typically occurs due to compatibility issues between these two libraries.

In the context provided, it was found that using Flask version 2.2.2 along with Werkzeug version 2.2.2 caused this error. The solution is to pin the version of Flask to an older version that is compatible with Werkzeug. Specifically, you can resolve this by installing Flask version 2.1.3 using the command:

```
pipenv install Flask==2.1.3
```

This should solve the issue related to the `unbound_message` error.
answer_orig:
Problem Description:
In video 10.3, when I was testing a flask service, I got the above error. I ran docker run .. in one terminal. When in second terminal I run python gateway.py, I get the above error.
Solution: This error has something to do with versions of Flask and Werkzeug. I got the same error, if I just import flask with from flask import Flask.
By running pip freeze > requirements.txt,I found that their versions are Flask==2.2.2 and Werkzeug==2.2.2. This error appears while using an old version of werkzeug (2.2.2) with new version of flask (2.2.2). I solved it by pinning version of Flask into an older version with pipenv install Flask==2.1.3.
Added by Bhaskar Sarma
question: What solution can you offer for the TypeError related to 'unbound_message' when importing Flask?

answer_llm:
The TypeError you are encountering in video 10.3 while running `docker` and then `python gateway.py` is due to an incompatibility between the versions of Flask and Werkzeug you are using. Specifically, the error message indicates that you are using an old version of Werkzeug (2.2.2) with a new version of Flask (2.2.2), leading to the TypeError.

To resolve this issue, you can pin the version of Flask to an older version. The solution is to run the following command:

```
pipenv install Flask==2.1.3
```

This action should solve the TypeError and allow your application to run correctly.

answer_llm:
When you get the error `aws: error: argument operation: Invalid choice` while using `aws ecr get-login --no-include-email`, you should use the command `aws ecr get-login-password` instead. This is the updated command to retrieve the password for logging in to your Amazon ECR. 

For example, you can log in using the following command, making sure to replace `<ACCOUNT_NUMBER>` and `<REGION>` with your specific values:

```bash
export PASSWORD=`aws ecr get-login-password`
docker login -u AWS -p $PASSWORD <ACCOUNT_NUMBER>.dkr.ecr.<REGION>.amazonaws.com
```

Alternatively, if you have a default region configured, you can use this command:

```bash
aws ecr get-login-password --region $(aws configure get region) | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin "$(aws sts get-caller-identity --query "Account" --output text).dkr.ecr.$(aws configure get region).amazonaws.com"
```
answer_orig:
As per AWS documentation:
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECR/latest/userguide/docker-push-ecr-image.html
You need to do: (change the fields in red)
aws ecr get-login-password --region region | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin aws_account_id.dkr.ecr.region.amazonaws.com
Alternatively you can run the following command without changing anything given you have a default region configured
aws ecr get-login-password --region $(aws configure get region) | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin "$(aws sts get-caller-identity --query "Account" --output text).dkr.ecr.$(aws configure get region).amazonaws.com"
Added by Humberto Rodriguez

answer_llm:
The solution for the TensorFlow Serving error on Apple M1 Mac is to use a different Docker image. You can resolve the error by running the following commands:

1. Pull the correct image:
   ```
   docker pull emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest
   ```

2. Run the Docker container with the correct parameters:
   ```
   docker run -it --rm \
   -p 8500:8500 \
   -v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
   -e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
   emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest-linux_arm64
   ```

For more information, you can refer to the GitHub repository: https://github.com/emacski/tensorflow-serving-arm.
answer_orig:
While trying to run the docker code on M1:
docker run --platform linux/amd64 -it --rm \
-p 8500:8500 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
-e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
tensorflow/serving:2.7.0
It outputs the error:
Error:
Status: Downloaded newer image for tensorflow/serving:2.7.0
[libprotobuf FATAL external/com_google_protobuf/src/google/protobuf/generated_message_reflection.cc:2345] CHECK failed: file != nullptr:
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'google::protobuf::FatalException'
what():  CHECK failed: file != nullptr:
qemu: uncaught target signal 6 (Aborted) - core dumped
/usr/bin/tf_serving_entrypoint.sh: line 3:     8 Aborted                 tensorflow_model_server --port=8500 --rest_api_port=8501 --model_name=${MODEL_NAME} --model_base_path=${MODEL_BASE_PATH}/${MODEL_NAME} "$@"
Solution
docker pull emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest
docker run -it --rm \
-p 8500:8500 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
-e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest-linux_arm64
See more here: https://github.com/emacski/tensorflow-serving-arm
Added by Daniel Egbo

question: How can I solve the error caused by 'libprotobuf FATAL' while downloading tensorflow/serving:2.7.0?

answer_llm:
The recommended Docker image to use for TensorFlow Serving on an M1 Mac is `emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest-linux_arm64`. To run it, you can use the following command:

```bash
docker run -it --rm \
-p 8500:8500 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
-e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest-linux_arm64
```

Alternatively, for better support, you can use the `bitnami/tensorflow-serving:2` image. Here’s a sample command:

```bash
docker run -d \
--name tf_serving \
-p 8500:8500 \
-p 8501:8501 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/bitnami/model-data/1 \
-e TENSORFLOW_SERVING_MODEL_NAME=clothing-model \
bitnami/tensorflow-serving:2
```

question: Who provided the solution for the TensorFlow Serving issue on Apple M1 Mac?

answer_llm:
If you encounter an Illegal instruction error while running the tensorflow/serving image on a Mac M2 Apple Silicon, you should switch to using the bitnami/tensorflow-serving base image. You can do this by running the following command:

```bash
docker run -d \
--name tf_serving \
-p 8500:8500 \
-p 8501:8501 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/bitnami/model-data/1 \
-e TENSORFLOW_SERVING_MODEL_NAME=clothing-model \
bitnami/tensorflow-serving:2
```

Alternatively, you can use a `docker-compose.yaml` file as follows:

```yaml
version: '3'
services:
  tf_serving:
    image: bitnami/tensorflow-serving:2
    volumes:
      - ${PWD}/clothing-model:/bitnami/model-data/1
    ports:
      - 8500:8500
      - 8501:8501
    environment:
      - TENSORFLOW_SERVING_MODEL_NAME=clothing-model
```

Then, you can run it with:

```bash
docker compose up
```

answer_llm:
If the HPA doesn’t show CPU metrics and displays "Unknown," you can try the following steps to resolve the issue:

1. Delete the existing HPA with the command:
   ```
   kubectl delete hpa credit-hpa
   ```
2. Apply the metrics server configuration using:
   ```
   kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pythianarora/total-practice/master/sample-kubernetes-code/metrics-server.yaml
   ```
3. Create the HPA again.

These steps should help solve the CPU metrics reporting issue.
answer_orig:
Problem: CPU metrics Shows Unknown
NAME         REFERENCE           TARGETS         MINPODS   MAXPODS   REPLICAS   AGE
credit-hpa   Deployment/credit   <unknown>/20%   1         3         1          18s
FailedGetResourceMetric       2m15s (x169 over 44m)  horizontal-pod-autoscaler  failed to get cpu utilization: unable to get metrics for resource cpu: unable to fetch metrics from resource metrics API:
Solution:
-> Delete HPA (kubectl delete hpa credit-hpa)
-> kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pythianarora/total-practice/master/sample-kubernetes-code/metrics-server.yaml
-> Create HPA
This should solve the cpu metrics report issue.
Added by Priya V

answer_llm:
To delete an HPA (Horizontal Pod Autoscaler) in Kubernetes, you can use the following command:

```
kubectl delete hpa <hpa-name>
```

For example, if you want to delete an HPA named `credit-hpa`, you would run:

```
kubectl delete hpa credit-hpa
```

answer_llm: If you encounter errors with Istio during KServe installation, you should first check your `kubectl` version to ensure it is greater than 1.25.0 by using the command `kubectl version`. If you face issues running the KServe quick install script, you need to download the `quick_install.sh` script without running it directly. Edit the file to update the versions of Istio and Knative according to the matrix available on the KServe website. After making the necessary edits, run the bash script again.
answer_orig:
Problem description:
Running this:
curl -s "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kserve/kserve/release-0.9/hack/quick_install.sh" | bash
Fails with errors because of istio failing to update resources, and you are on kubectl > 1.25.0.
Check kubectl version with kubectl version
Solution description
Edit the file “quick_install.bash” by downloading it with curl without running bash. Edit the versions of Istio and Knative as per the matrix on the KServe website.
Run the bash script now.
Added by Andrew Katoch

answer_llm: A midterm project should generally cover content up to module-06 of the course syllabus. You are encouraged to include any additional topics or modules you want to feature, but it's important to document anything not covered in class. The project should also involve identifying an interesting problem, finding a relevant dataset, describing the problem and how a model could be used, preparing the data, performing exploratory data analysis (EDA), training and tuning multiple models, and deploying the model locally with Docker, with bonus points for cloud deployment.

4. Train multiple models, tune their performance, and select the best model.

question: Will there be a compiled list of links to submitted projects for peer review?

answer_llm:
Emails in the peer review process for projects are hashed using the SHA-1 algorithm. To compute the hash value of your email address, you can use the following Python code:

```python
from hashlib import sha1
def compute_hash(email):
    return sha1(email.lower().encode('utf-8')).hexdigest()
```

You need to replace `"YOUR_EMAIL_HERE"` with your actual email address and run the code to obtain the hashed email. This hashed value is then used to identify your assigned peer projects in the review process. You can find the assigned projects by searching for your hashed email value in a provided spreadsheet.

answer_llm: For Point 4 in the midterm deliverables, you should train as many models as you can. The requirement is to "train multiple models," which means you need to have more than one model to be on the right track.

answer_llm:
To find the projects you need to review for the capstone, follow these steps:

1. Compute the hash value of your email address using the provided Python code. Replace "Example1@gmail.com" with your own email address.
2. Access the spreadsheet at the provided link: [Capstone Projects Spreadsheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vR-7RRtq7AMx5OzI-tDbkzsbxNLm-NvFOP5OfJmhCek9oYcDx5jzxtZW2ZqWvBqc395UZpHBv1of9R1/pubhtml?gid=876309294&single=true).
3. Search for your hashed email value in the spreadsheet under the (reviewer_hash) heading to find your assigned peer projects.

You are required to review 3 assigned peer projects, which will be indicated in the spreadsheet.
answer_orig:
I am not sure how the project evaluate assignment works? Where do I find this? I have access to all the capstone 2 project, perhaps, I can randomly pick any to review.
Answer:
The link provided for example (2023/Capstone link ): https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdgoepohpgbM4MWTAHWuXa6r3NXKnxKcg4NDOm0bElAdXdnnA/viewform contains a list of all submitted projects to be evaluated. More specific, you are to review 3 assigned peer projects. In the spreadsheet are 3 hash values of your assigned peer projects. However, you need to derive the your hash value of your email address and find the value on the spreadsheet under the (reviewer_hash) heading.
To calculate your hash value run the python code below:
from hashlib import sha1
def compute_hash(email):
return sha1(email.lower().encode('utf-8')).hexdigest()
# Example usage **** enter your email below (Example1@gmail.com)****
email = "Example1@gmail.com"
hashed_email = compute_hash(email)
print("Original Email:", email)
print("Hashed Email (SHA-1):", hashed_email)
Edit the above code to replace Example1@gmail.com as your email address
Store and run the above python code from your terminal. See below as the Hashed Email (SHA-1) value
You then go to the link: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vR-7RRtq7AMx5OzI-tDbkzsbxNLm-NvFOP5OfJmhCek9oYcDx5jzxtZW2ZqWvBqc395UZpHBv1of9R1/pubhtml?gid=876309294&single=true
Lastly, copy the “Hashed Email (SHA-1): bd9770be022dede87419068aa1acd7a2ab441675” value and search for 3 identical entries. There you should see your peer project to be reviewed.
By Emmanuel Ayeni

question: How will my peers review my midterm project?

question: What is the purpose of the train.py file?

answer_llm: You should include the train.py file in conda or pipenv because it will be used by your peers to review your midterm project. It allows them to cross-check that your training process works on someone else’s system, which is essential for collaboration and validation of your work. Additionally, running a Python script like train.py is much simpler and more representative of real-world training processes compared to running a Jupyter notebook (notebook.ipynb).
answer_orig:
Answer: The train.py file will be used by your peers to review your midterm project. It is for them to cross-check that your training process works on someone else’s system. It should also be included in the environment in conda or with pipenv.
Odimegwu David
question: Why should I include train.py in conda or pipenv?

answer_llm: The training process can be verified on another system by ensuring that all necessary components are in place for reproducibility. This includes having the appropriate dataset, clear instructions, and checking for any obvious errors. Additionally, if utilizing TensorFlow, reproducibility can be achieved by setting a random seed and enabling operation determinism. Following these guidelines allows verification of the training process across different systems.
answer_orig:
Answer: The train.py file will be used by your peers to review your midterm project. It is for them to cross-check that your training process works on someone else’s system. It should also be included in the environment in conda or with pipenv.

answer_llm: Instead of using `feature_importances_` in an XGboost model, you should use `get_score()` if you trained the model with `model = xgb.train`.
answer_orig:
Using model.feature_importances_ can gives you an error:
AttributeError: 'Booster' object has no attribute 'feature_importances_'
Answer: if you train the model like this: model = xgb.train you should use get_score() instead
Ekaterina Kutovaia
question: What should I use instead of feature_importances_ in an XGboost model?

answer_llm: To avoid the `AttributeError` when accessing feature importance in XGBoost, make sure you use the appropriate method depending on how you trained your model. If you trained the model using `model = xgb.train`, you should access feature importance with `get_score()` instead of `model.feature_importances_`.
answer_orig:
Using model.feature_importances_ can gives you an error:
AttributeError: 'Booster' object has no attribute 'feature_importances_'
Answer: if you train the model like this: model = xgb.train you should use get_score() instead
Ekaterina Kutovaia

answer_llm: To avoid a pickle attribute error when using waitress with your Docker container, you should place your custom column transformer class into a separate module and import it in both the script that saves the model (like `train.py`) and the script that loads the model (like `predict.py`). This is necessary because when the model is saved, it references the class in the `__main__` module, and using waitress changes the context from which the class is being called, resulting in the error.
answer_orig:
When running a docker container with waitress serving the app.py for making predictions, pickle will throw an error that can't get attribute <name_of_class> on module __main__.
This does not happen when Flask is used directly, i.e. not through waitress.
The problem is that the model uses a custom column transformer class, and when the model was saved, it was saved from the __main__ module (e.g. python train.py). Pickle will reference the class in the global namespace (top-level code): __main__.<custom_class>.
When using waitress, waitress will load the predict_app module and this will call pickle.load, that will try to find __main__.<custom_class> that does not exist.
Solution:
Put the class into a separate module and import it in both the script that saves the model (e.g. train.py) and the script that loads the model (e.g. predict.py)
Note: If Flask is used (no waitress) in predict.py, and predict.py has the definition of the class, When  it is run: python predict.py, it will work because the class is in the same namespace as the one used when the model was saved (__main__).
Detailed info: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27732354/unable-to-load-files-using-pickle-and-multiple-modules
Marcos MJD
question: How can I avoid a pickle attribute error when using waitress with my Docker container?

answer_llm: The attribute error in pickle when running a Docker container with waitress is caused by the use of a custom column transformer class that was saved from the `__main__` module when the model was trained (e.g., using `python train.py`). When using waitress, the `predict_app` module is loaded, and pickle looks for the class in the global namespace (`__main__.<custom_class>`), which does not exist in that context. This issue does not occur when using Flask directly because the class would be in the same namespace as when the model was saved. To resolve this, you should place the class in a separate module and import it in both the script that saves the model and the script that loads it.
answer_orig:
When running a docker container with waitress serving the app.py for making predictions, pickle will throw an error that can't get attribute <name_of_class> on module __main__.
This does not happen when Flask is used directly, i.e. not through waitress.
The problem is that the model uses a custom column transformer class, and when the model was saved, it was saved from the __main__ module (e.g. python train.py). Pickle will reference the class in the global namespace (top-level code): __main__.<custom_class>.
When using waitress, waitress will load the predict_app module and this will call pickle.load, that will try to find __main__.<custom_class> that does not exist.
Solution:
Put the class into a separate module and import it in both the script that saves the model (e.g. train.py) and the script that loads the model (e.g. predict.py)
Note: If Flask is used (no waitress) in predict.py, and predict.py has the definition of the class, When  it is run: python predict.py, it will work because the class is in the same namespace as the one used when the model was saved (__main__).
Detailed info: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27732354/unable-to-load-files-using-pickle-and-multiple-modules
Marcos MJD
question: What causes pickle to throw an attribute error when running a Docker container with waitress?

answer_llm:
The reason pickle works with Flask but not with waitress for your custom column transformer class is due to how the class is referenced in different contexts. When you save the model using pickle, it references the class in the global namespace as `__main__.<custom_class>`. This works in Flask because Flask runs the script where the class is defined in the `__main__` context.

However, when you use waitress, it loads the application from a different module, which does not have the `__main__` namespace containing the custom class. As a result, pickle cannot find the class and throws an error. 

The solution is to place the custom column transformer class in a separate module that can be imported both in the script that saves the model and in the script that loads it. This ensures that the class is correctly referenced regardless of whether Flask or waitress is used.
answer_orig:
When running a docker container with waitress serving the app.py for making predictions, pickle will throw an error that can't get attribute <name_of_class> on module __main__.

When using waitress, waitress will load the predict_app module and this will call pickle.load, that will try to find __main__.<custom_class> that does not exist.
Solution:
Put the class into a separate module and import it in both the script that saves the model (e.g. train.py) and the script that loads the model (e.g. predict.py)
Note: If Flask is used (no waitress) in predict.py, and predict.py has the definition of the class, When  it is run: python predict.py, it will work because the class is in the same namespace as the one used when the model was saved (__main__).
Detailed info: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27732354/unable-to-load-files-using-pickle-and-multiple-modules
Marcos MJD

answer_llm: To avoid pickle errors when using Waitress, you should modify your scripts by putting your custom column transformer class into a separate module. Common techniques to handle outliers in a dataset include:

1. Dataset transformation (for example, log transformation)
2. Clipping high values
3. Dropping these observations
answer_orig:
There are different techniques, but the most common used are the next:
Dataset transformation (for example, log transformation)
Clipping high values
Dropping these observations
Alena Kniazeva

This is one of various methods to handle outliers, along with dataset transformation and dropping observations.

answer_llm:
If Bento fails to import the module 'service' with a 'No module named sklearn' error, check your `bentofile.yaml` file. Ensure that you have listed the package as `scikit-learn` instead of `sklearn`. Modify the packages list to include `scikit-learn`, and the issue should be resolved. The updated packages list should look like this:

```yaml
packages: # Additional pip packages required by the service
- xgboost
- scikit-learn
- pydantic
```
answer_orig:
I was getting the below error message when I was trying to create docker image using bentoml
[bentoml-cli] `serve` failed: Failed loading Bento from directory /home/bentoml/bento: Failed to import module "service": No module named 'sklearn'
Solution description
The cause was because , in bentofile.yaml, I wrote sklearn instead of scikit-learn. Issue was fixed after I modified the packages list as below.
packages: # Additional pip packages required by the service
- xgboost
- scikit-learn
- pydantic
Asia Saeed

answer_llm: A long error message mentioning sparse matrices and a code 500 error with an empty string output in BentoML may be caused by setting DictVectorizer or One-Hot Encoder (OHE) to sparse during the training phase. When this configuration is stored in a pipeline or custom object, it can lead to inconsistent input sizes when calling the custom object in service.py, which prevents batching. To resolve this, the BentoML model signatures should have the `batchable` option set to False during the saving stage in train.py.
answer_orig:
You might see a long error message with something about sparse matrices, and in the swagger UI, you get a code 500 error with “” (empty string) as output.
Potential reason: Setting DictVectorizer or OHE to sparse while training, and then storing this in a pipeline or custom object in the benotml model saving stage in train.py. This means that when the custom object is called in service.py, it will convert each input to a different sized sparse matrix, and this can't be batched due to inconsistent length. In this case, bentoml model signatures should have batchable set to False for production during saving the bentoml mode in train.py.
(Memoona Tahira)
question: What might be the cause of a long error message with something about sparse matrices and a code 500 error with an empty string output in BentoML?

answer_llm: You may get different sized sparse matrices in BentoML production when using DictVectorizer or OneHotEncoder (OHE) during training due to the configuration of how these tools handle sparse matrices. If you set DictVectorizer or OHE to sparse while training and then save this configuration in a pipeline or custom object during the model saving stage, inconsistencies can arise. When the custom object is called in service.py, it can convert each input into a differently sized sparse matrix. Since these varying sizes cannot be batched together, you may encounter errors in production, such as a code 500 error. To address this issue, it is recommended to set the model signatures in BentoML to have batchable set to False when saving the model in train.py.
answer_orig:
You might see a long error message with something about sparse matrices, and in the swagger UI, you get a code 500 error with “” (empty string) as output.

This means that when the custom object is called in service.py, it will convert each input to a different sized sparse matrix, and this can't be batched due to inconsistent length. In this case, bentoml model signatures should have batchable set to False for production during saving the bentoml mode in train.py.
(Memoona Tahira)
question: Why do I get different sized sparse matrices in BentoML production when using DictVectorizer or OHE during training?

answer_llm: To avoid errors in production when using BentoML model signatures, you should set `batchable` to `False` when saving the BentoML model in `train.py`. This is necessary if you have set `DictVectorizer` or `One-Hot Encoder (OHE)` to sparse during training, as it can lead to inconsistent sizes of sparse matrices that cannot be batched.

(Memoona Tahira)
question: Which module should be modified to make bentoml production work if DictVectorizer or OHE is set to sparse?

answer_llm: A BentoML container could give a code 500 error with an empty string in the Swagger UI if there is an issue related to using sparse matrices during the model training stage. Specifically, if you set `DictVectorizer` or `OneHotEncoder` (OHE) to sparse while training and stored this in a pipeline or custom object during the model saving stage, the service may fail to handle inputs correctly. This happens because the custom object will convert each input into differently sized sparse matrices, which cannot be batched due to inconsistent lengths. To resolve this, the BentoML model signatures should have the `batchable` option set to `False` during the model saving process.
answer_orig:
You might see a long error message with something about sparse matrices, and in the swagger UI, you get a code 500 error with “” (empty string) as output.
Potential reason: Setting DictVectorizer or OHE to sparse while training, and then storing this in a pipeline or custom object in the benotml model saving stage in train.py. This means that when the custom object is called in service.py, it will convert each input to a different sized sparse matrix, and this can't be batched due to inconsistent length. In this case, bentoml model signatures should have batchable set to False for production during saving the bentoml mode in train.py.
(Memoona Tahira)

answer_llm:
You can find more information related to reproducibility in this course in the following sections:

1. The general problem description encourages you to run all provided files if possible, as this helps in learning from others, although it's acknowledged that not everyone may be able to run everything, particularly for neural networks.

2. Specific instructions for ensuring reproducibility with TensorFlow are provided, including the use of a seed point and enabling operation determinism. For detailed guidance, refer to the link: https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/r2.8/api_docs/python/tf/config/experimental/enable_op_determinism.

Additionally, there is a related Slack conversation for further discussion on reproducibility.

If you receive an "unauthorized" message when pushing a Docker image to Google Container Registry, it indicates that you do not have the necessary permissions or may have invalid credentials. To resolve this issue, you should first install the Google Cloud SDK by following the instructions at https://cloud.google.com/sdk/docs/install. After installation, run the following command in your console:

```
gcloud auth configure-docker
```
answer_orig:
When you try to push the docker image to Google Container Registry and get this message “unauthorized: You don't have the needed permissions to perform this operation, and you may have invalid credentials.”, type this below on console, but first install https://cloud.google.com/sdk/docs/install, this is to be able to use gcloud in console:
gcloud auth configure-docker
(Jesus Acuña)

answer_llm:
If you are unable to install `tflite_runtime` in a pipenv environment, it is likely due to a version compatibility issue, as `tflite_runtime` does not run on Python 3.10. To resolve this, you should install Python 3.9, which will allow you to install `tflite_runtime` without any problems.

You can also check the available versions for your operating system and Python version at this link: [TFLite Runtime Versions](https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/). If you do not find a suitable combination, consider using the options available at [another GitHub repository](https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite) and install a specific wheel file using pip, as shown in the lecture (e.g., `pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp38-cp38-linux_x86_64.whl`).

Alternatively, if none of these solutions work, you can use the TFLite included in TensorFlow for local development and test with Docker.
answer_orig:
I am getting this error message when I tried to install tflite in a pipenv environment
Error:  An error occurred while installing tflite_runtime!
Error text:
ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement tflite_runtime (from versions: none)
ERROR: No matching distribution found for tflite_runtime
This version of tflite do not run on python 3.10, the way we can make it work is by install python 3.9, after that it would install the tflite_runtime without problem.
Pastor Soto
Check all available versions here:
https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/
If you don’t find a combination matching your setup, try out the options at
https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite
which you can install as shown in the lecture, e.g.
pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp38-cp38-linux_x86_64.whl
Finally, if nothing works, use the TFLite included in TensorFlow for local development, and use Docker for testing Lambda.
Rileen Sinha (based on discussions on Slack)
question: What should I do if I'm unable to install tflite_runtime in a pipenv environment?

If the standard installation methods don't work, you can try installing Kind via the Go package. Follow these steps:

1. Download and Install Go from [here](https://go.dev/doc/install).
2. Confirm the installation by typing `go version` in the Command Prompt.
3. Proceed to install Kind using the command `go install sigs.k8s.io/kind@v0.20.0`.
4. Confirm the installation with `kind --version`.

This method should work perfectly if the other installation methods fail.

answer_llm:

1. Check that scipy is installed in your environment.

If you are using SaturnCloud, you may also need to add scipy in the "Extra Packages" section while creating the Jupyter server resource to ensure it's automatically installed when the resource spins up.

If you get an UnidentifiedImageError while testing a model locally on a test-image data, the solution is to add "?raw=true" after the .jpg in your URL. For example, you should change your URL to: 

```
url = 'https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg?raw=true'
```
answer_orig:
In deploying model part, I wanted to test my model locally on a test-image data and I had this silly error after the following command:
url = 'https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg'
X = preprocessor.from_url(url)
I got the error:
UnidentifiedImageError: cannot identify image file <_io.BytesIO object at 0x7f797010a590>
Solution:
Add ?raw=true after .jpg in url. E.g. as below
url = ‘https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg?raw=true’
Bhaskar Sarma

to

answer_llm: If you see `[pipenv.exceptions.ResolutionFailure]` while running `pipenv install`, it indicates that your dependencies could not be resolved due to a likely mismatch in your sub-dependencies. To address this issue, you should manually change your `Pipfile` and `Pipfile.lock`, and then run `pipenv lock` to fix the problem and update your dependency files.

If you're encountering a `[pipenv.exceptions.ResolutionFailure]` warning, this indicates a mismatch in your sub-dependencies, and following the above steps should help address that issue.

answer_llm: The error 'Expecting value: line 1 column 1 (char 0)' when decoding JSON response occurs when the server receives data in a format that is not suitable for the model. Specifically, this happens when the format input to the model isn’t in the correct shape. The server expects the data in JSON format (as a dictionary), but if it's not formatted properly, the decoding fails. To resolve this, ensure that the data is converted to the appropriate format, such as numpy arrays.

answer_llm:
To convert the `day_of_the_month` and `month_of_the_year` columns into a single `day_of_the_year` column in pandas, you can follow these steps:

1. Convert the `day_of_the_month` column from integer type to string type:
   ```python
   df['day_of_the_month'] = df['day_of_the_month'].map(str)
   ```

2. Convert the `month_of_the_year` column (which contains strings like 'jan', 'feb', etc.) into corresponding month numbers as strings:
   ```python
   month_mapping = {'jan': '1', 'feb': '2', 'mar': '3', 'apr': '4', 'may': '5', 'jun': '6', 
                    'jul': '7', 'aug': '8', 'sep': '9', 'oct': '10', 'nov': '11', 'dec': '12'}
   df['month'] = df['month_of_the_year'].map(month_mapping)
   ```

3. Create a datetime object using the `day` and `month` columns:
   ```python
   df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(
       dict(
           year='2055',
           month=df['month'],
           day=df['day']
       )
   )
   ```

4. Get the day of the year from the `date_formatted` column:
   ```python
   df['day_of_year'] = df['date_formatted'].dt.dayofyear
   ```

This will give you a `day_of_year` column that represents the day of the year as an integer.

I want to convert these two columns into one column day_of_the_year and I want them to be int. 2 and jan should give me 2, i.e. 2nd day of the year, 1 and feb should give me 32, i.e. 32 nd day of the year. What is the simplest pandas-way to do it?

convert dtype in day_of_the_month column from int to str with df['day_of_the_month'] = df['day_of_the_month'].map(str)
convert month_of_the_year column in jan, feb ...,dec into 1,2, ..,12 string using map()
convert day and month into a datetime object with:
df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(
dict(
year='2055',
month=df['month'],
day=df['day']
)
)
get day of year with: df['day_of_year']=df['date_formatted'].dt.dayofyear
(Bhaskar Sarma)

answer_llm:
To transform 'month_of_the_year' values like 'jan' and 'feb' into integers in pandas, you can use the `map()` function to convert the string representations of the months into their corresponding integers. Here's a step-by-step approach:

1. Use `map()` to convert 'jan', 'feb', ..., 'dec' into 1, 2, ..., 12.
2. Combine this with the day of the month to create a datetime object.
3. Finally, extract the day of the year from this datetime object.

Here’s a simplified example based on the provided context:

```python
import pandas as pd

# Example DataFrame
df = pd.DataFrame({
    'day_of_the_month': [1, 2, 20, 25],
    'month_of_the_year': ['jan', 'feb', 'mar', 'apr']
})

# Convert day of the month to string
df['day_of_the_month'] = df['day_of_the_month'].map(str)

# Map month strings to integers
month_mapping = {'jan': 1, 'feb': 2, 'mar': 3, 'apr': 4, 'may': 5, 'jun': 6, 
                 'jul': 7, 'aug': 8, 'sep': 9, 'oct': 10, 'nov': 11, 'dec': 12}
df['month'] = df['month_of_the_year'].map(month_mapping)

# Create datetime from day and month
df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(
    dict(
        year='2055',  # Example year
        month=df['month'],
        day=df['day_of_the_month']
    )
)

# Get day of the year
df['day_of_year'] = df['date_formatted'].dt.dayofyear
```

In this example, the 'month_of_the_year' values are successfully transformed into integers corresponding to their month numbers.

question: How do I transform month_of_the_year values like 'jan' and 'feb' into integers in pandas?

answer_llm:
To format day and month columns into a datetime object using pandas, you can follow these steps:

1. Convert the `day_of_the_month` column from int to str:
   ```python
   df['day_of_the_month'] = df['day_of_the_month'].map(str)
   ```

2. Convert the `month_of_the_year` column (with values like 'jan', 'feb', etc.) into corresponding month numbers as strings (1, 2, ..., 12):
   ```python
   df['month'] = df['month_of_the_year'].map({'jan': '1', 'feb': '2', 'mar': '3', 'apr': '4', 'may': '5', 'jun': '6', 'jul': '7', 'aug': '8', 'sep': '9', 'oct': '10', 'nov': '11', 'dec': '12'})
   ```

3. Create a datetime object with the formatted day and month:
   ```python
   df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(
       dict(
           year='2055',  # You can specify any year you like
           month=df['month'],
           day=df['day_of_the_month']
       )
   )
   ```

4. If you need to get the day of the year, you can then add:
   ```python
   df['day_of_year'] = df['date_formatted'].dt.dayofyear
   ``` 

These steps will effectively combine the day and month into a single datetime object in your DataFrame.

question: What steps are needed to format day and month columns into a datetime object using pandas?

answer_llm:
To get the day of the year from a date formatted column using pandas, you can follow these steps:

1. Convert the `day_of_the_month` column from int to str:
   ```python
   df['day_of_the_month'] = df['day_of_the_month'].map(str)
   ```

2. Convert the `month_of_the_year` column (which contains values like 'jan', 'feb', etc.) into corresponding month numbers (1 for 'jan', 2 for 'feb', etc.) using the `map()` function.

3. Create a datetime object by combining the day and month:
   ```python
   df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(
       dict(
           year='2055',  # You can set any year; it's needed for the datetime conversion
           month=df['month'],
           day=df['day']
       )
   )
   ```

4. Finally, get the day of the year:
   ```python
   df['day_of_year'] = df['date_formatted'].dt.dayofyear
   ```

These steps will give you a new column `day_of_year` which contains the day of the year as integers.

To create a bar chart for predictions, follow these steps:

1. Prepare your classes and predictions data:
   ```python
   classes, predictions = zip(*dict(zip(classes, predictions)).items())
   ```

2. Set up the figure for the bar chart:
   ```python
   plt.figure(figsize=(12, 3))
   ```

3. Create the bar chart using the classes and predictions:
   ```python
   plt.bar(classes, predictions)
   ```

4. Optionally, you can add labels and a title to your chart for clarity:
   ```python
   plt.xlabel('Classes')
   plt.ylabel('Predictions')
   plt.title('Bar Chart of Predictions per Class')
   ```

5. Finally, display the chart:
   ```python
   plt.show()
   ```

To install the CUDA toolkit and cuDNN for TensorFlow on Windows, follow these steps:

1. **Install Nvidia Drivers**: Download and install the appropriate Nvidia drivers from https://www.nvidia.com/download/index.aspx.

2. **Install Anaconda**: Download and install Anaconda from https://www.anaconda.com/.

3. **Install TensorFlow**: You have two options for installing TensorFlow:
   - Install the package ‘tensorflow-gpu’ using Anaconda.
   - Use the TensorFlow installation guide: https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#windows-native.

4. **Install CUDA Toolkit**: Download and install the CUDA toolkit 11.x.x from https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit-archive.

5. **Install cuDNN**: Download and install cuDNN from https://developer.nvidia.com/rdp/cudnn-download.

After completing these steps, you should be able to train and perform inference with GPU support in TensorFlow.

1. Install Anaconda from [Anaconda's official website](https://www.anaconda.com/).

answer_llm:
You can find help for uploading datasets on Kaggle by following the steps outlined in the context for using Kaggle with Saturn Cloud. Here’s a summary of the process:

1. Install the Kaggle package in your notebook by running: 
   ```bash
   !pip install -q kaggle
   ```

2. Go to the Kaggle website (you'll need to have an account), click on your profile image, and navigate to Account settings. 

3. Scroll down to the API box, click on "Create New API token," which will download a `kaggle.json` file to your local computer.

4. Upload the `kaggle.json` file into the `.kaggle` folder in your notebook environment.

5. Change the permissions of the `kaggle.json` file using:
   ```bash
   !chmod 600 /home/jovyan/.kaggle/kaggle.json
   ```

6. To download a dataset, use the command:
   ```bash
   !kaggle datasets download -d <dataset-name>
   ```

7. Finally, create a folder to unzip your files and unzip them using:
   ```bash
   !mkdir data
   !unzip <dataset-file-name>.zip -d data
   ```

This method will allow you to access all Kaggle datasets directly in your environment.

answer_llm: The order is important in matrix multiplication because changing the order of the matrices usually results in matrices of different sizes and different values. Specifically, multiplying matrix A (m x n) by matrix B (n x p) yields a matrix C (m x p), while multiplying B (n x p) by A (m x n) results in a different matrix D (n x n). Therefore, the sequence in which the matrices are multiplied affects both the dimensions and the resulting values of the output matrix.
answer_orig:
When multiplying matrices, the order of multiplication is important.
For example:
A (m x n) * B (n x p) = C (m x p)
B (n x p) * A (m x n) = D (n x n)
C and D are matrices of different sizes and usually have different values. Therefore the order is important in matrix multiplication and changing the order changes the result.
Baran Akın
question: Why is the order important in matrix multiplication?

answer_llm: When changing the order in matrix multiplication, the result will be different. The order is important because multiplying matrix A (m x n) by matrix B (n x p) gives a matrix C (m x p), while multiplying matrix B (n x p) by matrix A (m x n) gives a different matrix D (n x n). Since C and D are matrices of different sizes and usually contain different values, changing the order of multiplication changes the result.
answer_orig:
When multiplying matrices, the order of multiplication is important.
For example:
A (m x n) * B (n x p) = C (m x p)
B (n x p) * A (m x n) = D (n x n)
C and D are matrices of different sizes and usually have different values. Therefore the order is important in matrix multiplication and changing the order changes the result.
Baran Akın
question: What happens if I change the order in matrix multiplication?

answer_llm: The size of the resulting matrix changes with the order of multiplication. Specifically, when multiplying two matrices, the number of columns in the first matrix must match the number of rows in the second matrix. The resulting matrix will have dimensions defined by the number of rows of the first matrix and the number of columns of the second matrix. For example, if you have matrices A (m x n) and B (n x p), multiplying them as A * B results in a matrix C (m x p). However, if you reverse the order and multiply B * A, the resulting matrix D will have dimensions (n x n). Thus, the order of multiplication affects both the size and the values of the resulting matrices.
answer_orig:
When multiplying matrices, the order of multiplication is important.
For example:

B (n x p) * A (m x n) = D (n x n)
C and D are matrices of different sizes and usually have different values. Therefore the order is important in matrix multiplication and changing the order changes the result.
Baran Akın
question: How does the size of the resulting matrix change with the order of multiplication?

answer_llm: No, multiplying matrices in a different order does not produce the same result. The order of multiplication is important in matrix multiplication; changing the order changes the result and typically produces matrices of different sizes and values.

question: Can multiplying matrices in a different order produce the same result?

answer_llm:
An example illustrating the impact of changing the order in matrix multiplication is as follows:

Let matrix A be of size m x n and matrix B be of size n x p. When we multiply them in the order A * B, we obtain a resulting matrix C of size m x p. However, if we change the order and multiply B * A instead, we get a different resulting matrix D of size n x n. Since C and D are matrices of different sizes, they will usually contain different values as well. This example highlights that changing the order of multiplication leads to different results, emphasizing that the order is crucial in matrix multiplication.
answer_orig:

B (n x p) * A (m x n) = D (n x n)
C and D are matrices of different sizes and usually have different values. Therefore the order is important in matrix multiplication and changing the order changes the result.

question: Why must my GitHub repository be public for this course?

answer_llm:
To set up a Conda environment on your computer, you need to follow these steps:

1. **Install Anaconda or Miniconda**: If you don’t have either installed, you should install it first.

2. **Create the Environment**: Run the command `conda create -n ml-zoomcamp python=3.9` (or replace `3.9` with `3.8` or `3.10` if you prefer a different version).

3. **Activate the Environment**: After the environment is created, you just need to run `conda activate ml-zoomcamp` whenever you want to use it.

4. **Export Environment (optional)**: You can export your existing environment to a YAML file using `conda env export > environment.yml`. This allows you to reproduce your environment later with `conda env create -f environment.yml`.

Make sure to open Anaconda’s own terminal if you are using Windows.

answer_llm: To resolve the error of Python 3.11 not being found when rerunning a docker file in Windows, you should add the Python311 installation folder to the PATH environment variable. After making this change, restart your system and then try running the docker file again. This should solve the error.
answer_orig:
When trying to rerun the docker file in Windows, as opposed to developing in WSL/Linux, I got the error of:
```
Warning: Python 3.11 was not found on your system…
Neither ‘pipenv’ nor ‘asdf’ could be found to install Python.
You can specify specific versions of Python with:
$ pipenv –python path\to\python
```
The solution was to add Python311 installation folder to the PATH and restart the system and run the docker file again. That solved the error.
(Added by Abhijit Chakraborty)
question: How can I resolve the error when rerunning a docker file in Windows compared to WSL/Linux if Python 3.11 is not found?

answer_llm: If neither 'pipenv' nor 'asdf' can be found to install Python on Windows, the solution is to ensure that the Python installation folder is added to the PATH. After adding the appropriate Python installation folder (such as `C:\Users\AppData\....\Python\PythonXX\` and `C:\Users\AppData\....\Python\PythonXX\Scripts\`) to the PATH, restart your system and try running your command again.

You can specify specific versions of Python when rerunning a Docker file by using the command:

```

```

Additionally, ensure that the Python version in your Dockerfile matches the version installed on your system. For example, if you want to use Python 3.9.7, you would have the first line of your Dockerfile as:

```
FROM python:3.9.7-slim
``` 

Make sure to verify your installed Python version with the command `python --version`.

answer_llm: Deploying to DigitalOcean App Cloud costs about 5 USD per month, and the container needs to be maintained until the end of the project evaluation.
answer_orig:
You may quickly deploy your project to DigitalOcean App Cloud. The process is relatively straightforward. The deployment costs about 5 USD/month. The container needs to be up until the end of the project evaluation.
Steps:
Register in DigitalOcean
Go to Apps -> Create App.
You will need to choose GitHub as a service provider.
Edit Source Directory (if your project is not in the repo root)
IMPORTANT: Go to settings -> App Spec and edit the Dockerfile path so it looks like ./project/Dockerfile path relative to your repo root
Remember to add model files if they are not built automatically during the container build process.
By Dmytro Durach

answer_llm: No, it is not necessarily best to train a model only on the most important features. While some features may be more important than others, any feature that can offer additional predictive value should be included in the model. It is suggested to predict with and without including specific features, and if excluding a feature drops performance, it should be kept; otherwise, it can be dropped. Moreover, features that seem individually important might be highly correlated with others, so including a broader set of features could be beneficial. Feature selection algorithms can also be explored to aid in this process.
answer_orig:
I’m just looking back at the lessons in week 3 (churn prediction project), and lesson 3.6 talks about Feature Importance for categorical values. At 8.12, the mutual info scores show that the some features are more important than others, but then in lesson 3.10 the Logistic Regression model is trained on all of the categorical variables (see 1:35). Once we have done feature importance, is it best to train your model only on the most important features?
Not necessarily - rather, any feature that can offer additional predictive value should be included (so, e.g. predict with & without including that feature; if excluding it drops performance, keep it, else drop it). A few individually important features might in fact be highly correlated with others, & dropping some might be fine. There are many feature selection algorithms, it might be interesting to read up on them (among the methods we've learned so far in this course, L1 regularization (Lasso) implicitly does feature selection by shrinking some weights all the way to zero).
By Rileen Sinha
question: Is it always best to train a model only on the most important features?

answer_llm: In lesson 3.6, the example that covers Feature Importance for categorical values is related to the churn prediction project. It discusses how mutual information scores indicate that some features are more important than others.

Not necessarily - rather, any feature that can offer additional predictive value should be included (so, e.g. predict with & without including that feature; if excluding it drops performance, keep it, else drop it). A few individually important features might in fact be highly correlated with others, & dropping some might be fine. There are many feature selection algorithms, it might be interesting to read up on them (among the methods we've learned so far in this course, L1 regularization (Lasso) implicitly does feature selection by shrinking some weights all the way to zero).
By Rileen Sinha
question: What method implicitly performs feature selection by shrinking some weights to zero?

answer_llm: Yes, some important features might be highly correlated with others and can be dropped without significantly affecting performance. After assessing feature importance, it's advisable to test the model with and without the correlated features to see if excluding any of them drops performance. If excluding a feature does not negatively impact performance, it can be safely removed.
answer_orig:
I’m just looking back at the lessons in week 3 (churn prediction project), and lesson 3.6 talks about Feature Importance for categorical values. At 8.12, the mutual info scores show that the some features are more important than others, but then in lesson 3.10 the Logistic Regression model is trained on all of the categorical variables (see 1:35). Once we have done feature importance, is it best to train your model only on the most important features?
Not necessarily - rather, any feature that can offer additional predictive value should be included (so, e.g. predict with & without including that feature; if excluding it drops performance, keep it, else drop it). A few individually important features might in fact be highly correlated with others, & dropping some might be fine. There are many feature selection algorithms, it might be interesting to read up on them (among the methods we've learned so far in this course, L1 regularization (Lasso) implicitly does feature selection by shrinking some weights all the way to zero).
By Rileen Sinha

answer_llm: It seems that your question is quite broad. If you have a specific question related to the course, please provide more details so I can assist you better. answer_orig:
You can consider several different approaches:
Sampling: In the exploratory phase, you can use random samples of the data.
Chunking: When you do need all the data, you can read and process it in chunks that do fit in the memory.
Optimizing data types: Pandas’ automatic data type inference (when reading data in) might result in e.g. float64 precision being used to represent integers, which wastes space. You might achieve substantial memory reduction by optimizing the data types.
Using Dask, an open-source python project which parallelizes Numpy and Pandas.
(see, e.g. https://www.vantage-ai.com/en/blog/4-strategies-how-to-deal-with-large-datasets-in-pandas)
By Rileen Sinha

question: What is the necessary condition for TensorFlow and TensorFlow Serving versions to work together?

answer_llm:
If the TensorFlow Serving image isn't working properly, you can check a few potential solutions:

1. Ensure that the TensorFlow (TF) and TensorFlow Serving versions match, as mismatched versions can cause issues.
2. For users running on Apple M2 or M1, it is recommended to use the `bitnami/tensorflow-serving` base image to avoid illegal instruction errors. You can do this by running:
   ```bash
   docker run -d \
   --name tf_serving \
   -p 8500:8500 \
   -p 8501:8501 \
   -v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/bitnami/model-data/1 \
   -e TENSORFLOW_SERVING_MODEL_NAME=clothing-model \
   bitnami/tensorflow-serving:2
   ```
3. In case of specific errors related to downloading or running the TensorFlow Serving image on Apple M1, try pulling the `emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest-linux_arm64` image and running it with:
   ```bash
   docker run -it --rm \
   -p 8500:8500 \
   -v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
   -e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
   emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest-linux_arm64
   ``` 

These solutions are derived from common issues reported with TensorFlow Serving images.

The TF and TF Serving versions have to match (as per solution from the slack channel)
